item.title: OpenStack SDN - OpenContrail With BGP VPN
item.description: In this post I’ll show how to build a dockerized OpenStack and OpenContrail lab, integrate it with Juniper MX80 DC-GW and demonstrate one of Contrail’s most interesting and unique features called BGP-as-a-Service

item.title: OpenStack SDN - OpenDaylight With BGP VPN
item.description: In this post I’ll demonstrate how to build a simple OpenStack lab with OpenDaylight-managed virtual networking and integrate it with a Cisco IOS-XE data centre gateway using EVPN

item.title: OpenStack SDN - NFV Management and Orchestration
item.description: In this post I’ll have a brief look at the NFV MANO framework developed by ETSI and create a simple vIDS network service using Tacker

item.title: OpenStack SDN - Skydiving Into Service Function Chaining
item.description: In this post I’ll show how to configure Neutron’s service function chaining, troubleshoot it with Skydive and how SFC is implemented in OVS forwarding pipeline

item.title: OpenStack SDN - Building a Containerized OpenStack Lab
item.description: I’m returning to my OpenStack SDN series to explore some of the new platform features like service function chaining, network service orchestration, intent-based networking and dynamic WAN routing. To kick things off I’m going to demonstrate my new fully-containerized OpenStack Lab that I’ve built using an OpenStack project called Kolla

item.title: OpenStack SDN With OVN (Part 2) - Network Engineering Analysis
item.description: In this post we will see how OVN implements virtual networks for OpenStack. The structure of this post is such that starting from the highest level of networking abstraction we will delve deeper into implementation details with each subsequent section. The biggest emphasis will be on how networking data model gets transformed into a set of logical flows, which eventually become OpenFlow flows. The final section will introduce a new overlay protocol GENEVE and explain why VXLAN no longer satisfies the needs of an overlay protocol.

item.title: OpenStack SDN With OVN (Part 1) - Build and Install
item.description: This is a first of a two-post series dedicated to project OVN. In this post I’ll show how to build, install and configure OVN to work with a 3-node RDO OpenStack lab

item.title: OpenStack SDN - Distributed Virtual Routing
item.description: In this post we’ll explore how DVR is implemented in OpenStack Neutron and what are some of its benefits and shortcomings

item.title: Automating the Build of OpenStack Lab (Part 2)
item.description: In this post we’ll use Chef, unnumbered BGP and Cumulus VX to build a massively scalable ‘Lapukhov’ Leaf-Spine data centre

item.title: Automating the Build of OpenStack Lab (Part 1)
item.description: In this post we will explore what’s required to perform a zero-touch deployment of an OpenStack cloud. We’ll get a 3-node lab up and running inside UNetLab with just a few commands

item.title: OpenStack SDN - Interconnecting VMs and Physical Devices With Cumulus VX L2 Gateway
item.description: One of the basic function of any data centre network is the ability to communicate with baremetal servers. In this post we’ll see how Neutron L2 Gateway plugin can be used to configure a Cumulus VX switch for VXLAN-VLAN bridging.

item.title: OpenStack SDN - Extending a L2 Provider Network Over a L3 Fabric
item.description: In the this post we’ll tackle yet another Neutron scalability problem identified in my earlier post- a requirement to have a direct L2 adjacency between the external provider network and the network node

item.title: OpenStack SDN - L2 Population and ARP Proxy
item.description: In the previous post we’ve had a look at how native OpenStack SDN works and what are some of its limitations. In this post we’ll tackle the first one of them - overhead created by multicast source replication

item.title: Network Engineering Analysis of OpenStack SDN
item.description: Now that we have our 3-node OpenStack lab [up and running][openstack-post-2] we can start exploring how virtual networks are implemented under the hood

item.title: Building a Multi-node OpenStack Lab in UNetLab
item.description: In the previous post I’ve demonstrated how to get a working instance of a single-node OpenStack inside UNetLab. In this post we’ll continue building on that by adding two new compute nodes and redesigning our network to resemble something you might actually see in a real life.

item.title: OpenStack on UNetlab
item.description: In this post I’m going to show how to get a running instance of OpenStack inside a UNetLab virtual machine
